[[13]](#cite_note-13) Measles is an [airborne disease](/wiki/Airborne_disease) which [spreads easily from one person to the next](/wiki/Human-to-human_transmission) through the [coughs](/wiki/Cough) and [sneezes](/wiki/Sneeze) of infected people. [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) It may also be spread through direct contact with mouth or [nasal secretions](/wiki/Mucus). [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2019News-14) It is extremely contagious: nine out of ten people who are not immune and share living space with an infected person will be infected. [[5]](#cite_note-CDC2012Pink-5) Furthermore, measles's [reproductive number](/wiki/Reproductive_number) estimates vary beyond the frequently cited range of 12 to 18. [[15]](#cite_note-15) The NIH quote this 2017 paper saying: "[a] review 2017 identified feasible measles R0 values of 3.7-203.3". [[16]](#cite_note-16) People are infectious to others from four days before to four days after the start of the rash. [[5]](#cite_note-CDC2012Pink-5) While often regarded as a childhood illness, it can affect people of any age. [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) Most people do not get the disease more than once. [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) Testing for the measles virus in suspected cases is important for public health efforts. [[5]](#cite_note-CDC2012Pink-5) Measles is not known to occur in other animals. [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2019News-14) Once a person has become infected, no specific treatment is available, [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2019News-14) although [supportive care](/wiki/Supportive_care) may improve outcomes. [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) Such care may include [oral rehydration solution](/wiki/Oral_rehydration_solution) (slightly sweet and salty fluids), healthy food, and medications to control the fever. [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) [[8]](#cite_note-Conn2014-8) [Antibiotics](/wiki/Antibiotics) should be prescribed if secondary bacterial infections such as ear infections or pneumonia occur. [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2019News-14) [Vitamin A](/wiki/Vitamin_A) supplementation is also recommended for children. [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2019News-14) Among cases reported in the U.S. between 1985 and 1992, death occurred in only 0.2% of cases, [[5]](#cite_note-CDC2012Pink-5) but may be up to 10% in people with [malnutrition](/wiki/Malnutrition). [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) Most of those who die from the infection are less than five years old. [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2019News-14) The [measles vaccine](/wiki/Measles_vaccine) is effective at preventing the disease, is exceptionally safe, and is often delivered [in combination](/wiki/MMR_vaccine) with other vaccines. [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) [[18]](#cite_note-Russell2019-18) [Vaccination](/wiki/Vaccination) resulted in an 80% decrease in deaths from measles between 2000 and 2017, with about 85% of children worldwide having received their first dose as of 2017. [[14]](#cite_note-WHO2019News-14) Measles affects about 20 million people a year, [[3]](#cite_note-MM2014-3) primarily in the developing areas of Africa and Asia. [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) It is one of the leading vaccine-preventable disease causes of death. [[19]](#cite_note-Kabra2013-19) [[20]](#cite_note-20) In 1980, 2.6 million people died from measles, [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) and in 1990, 545,000 died due to the disease; by 2014, global vaccination programs had reduced the number of deaths from measles to 73,000. [[21]](#cite_note-GBD2015De-21) [[22]](#cite_note-GDB2013-22) Despite these trends, rates of disease and deaths increased from 2017 to 2019 due to a decrease in immunization. [[23]](#cite_note-23) [[24]](#cite_note-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) Signs and symptoms Symptoms typically begin 10-14 days after exposure. [[26]](#cite_note-Pink2016-26) [[27]](#cite_note-Merk2018Pro-27) The classic symptoms include a four-day fever (the 4 D's) and the three C's— [cough](/wiki/Cough), [coryza](/wiki/Rhinitis) (head cold, fever, sneezing), and [conjunctivitis](/wiki/Conjunctivitis) (red eyes)—along with a [maculopapular rash](/wiki/Maculopapular_rash). [[28]](#cite_note-Biesbroeck2013-28) Fever is common and typically lasts for about one week; the fever seen with measles is often as high as 40 °C (104 °F). [[29]](#cite_note-Ludlow2015-29) [Koplik's spots](/wiki/Koplik%27s_spots) seen inside the mouth are diagnostic for measles, but are temporary and therefore rarely seen. [[28]](#cite_note-Biesbroeck2013-28) Koplik spots are small white spots that are commonly seen on the inside of the cheeks opposite the molars. [[27]](#cite_note-Merk2018Pro-27) They appear as "grains of salt on a reddish background." [[30]](#cite_note-Steichen-30) Recognizing these spots before a person reaches their maximum infectiousness can help reduce the spread of the disease. [[31]](#cite_note-baxby-31) The characteristic measles [rash](/wiki/Rash) is classically described as a generalized [red](/wiki/Erythema) maculopapular rash that begins several days after the fever starts. It starts on the back of the ears and, after a few hours, spreads to the head and neck before spreading to cover most of the body, often causing [itching](/wiki/Itch). The measles rash appears two to four days after the initial symptoms and lasts for up to eight days. The rash is said to "stain", changing color from red to dark brown, before disappearing. [[32]](#cite_note-32) Overall, measles usually resolves after about three weeks. [[29]](#cite_note-Ludlow2015-29) People who have been vaccinated against measles but have incomplete protective immunity may experience a form of modified measles. [[33]](#cite_note-:11-33) Modified measles is characterized by a prolonged [incubation period](/wiki/Incubation_period), milder, and less characteristic symptoms (sparse and discrete rash of short duration). [[33]](#cite_note-:11-33) - A Filipino baby with measles - [Koplik's spots](/wiki/Koplik%27s_spots)on the third pre-eruptive day - Koplik's spots on the day of measles [rash](/wiki/Rash) Complications Complications of measles are relatively common, ranging from mild ones such as [diarrhea](/wiki/Diarrhea) to serious ones such as [pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia) (either direct [viral pneumonia](/wiki/Viral_pneumonia) or secondary [bacterial pneumonia](/wiki/Bacterial_pneumonia)), [[36]](#cite_note-36) and in about 1 in 600 unvaccinated infants under 15 months while more rarely in older children and adults, [subacute sclerosing panencephalitis](/wiki/Subacute_sclerosing_panencephalitis), which is progressive and eventually lethal. [[37]](#cite_note-37) In addition, measles can suppress the immune system for weeks to months, and this can contribute to bacterial superinfections such as otitis media and bacterial pneumonia. [[6]](#cite_note-Rot2016-6) [[38]](#cite_note-38) [[39]](#cite_note-39) [[40]](#cite_note-Amnesia-40) [[41]](#cite_note-Mina_2019-41) Two months after recovery there is a 11-73% decrease in the number of antibodies against other bacteria and viruses. [[42]](#cite_note-Nature-42) The death rate in the 1920s was around 30% for measles pneumonia. [[43]](#cite_note-43) People who are at high risk for complications are infants and children aged less than 5 years; [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) adults aged over 20 years; [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) pregnant women; [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) people with compromised immune systems, such as from [leukemia](/wiki/Leukemia), HIV infection or innate immunodeficiency; [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) [[44]](#cite_note-cdc.gov-44) and those [vitamin A deficiency](/wiki/Vitamin_A_deficiency). [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) [[45]](#cite_note-45) Complications are usually more severe in adults. [[46]](#cite_note-46) Between 1987 and 2000, the case fatality rate across the United States was three deaths per 1,000 cases attributable to measles, or 0.3%. [[47]](#cite_note-The_Clinical_Significance_of_Measles:_A_Review-47) In [underdeveloped nations](/wiki/Developing_country) with high rates of malnutrition and poor [healthcare](/wiki/Healthcare), fatality rates have been as high as 28%. [[47]](#cite_note-The_Clinical_Significance_of_Measles:_A_Review-47) In immunocompromised persons (e.g., people with [AIDS](/wiki/AIDS)) the fatality rate is approximately 30%. [[48]](#cite_note-Sension1988-48) Even in previously healthy children, measles can cause serious illness requiring hospitalization. [[44]](#cite_note-cdc.gov-44) One out of every 1,000 measles cases progresses to acute [encephalitis](/wiki/Encephalitis), which often results in permanent brain damage. [[44]](#cite_note-cdc.gov-44) One to three out of every 1,000 children who become infected with measles will die from respiratory and neurological complications. [[44]](#cite_note-cdc.gov-44) Cause Measles is caused within the family [Paramyxoviridae](/wiki/Paramyxoviridae). [[49]](#cite_note-Cohen2014-49) The virus is highly contagious and is spread by coughing and sneezing via close personal contact or direct contact with secretions. [[50]](#cite_note-CDC2018Health-50) Measles is the most contagious virus known. [[18]](#cite_note-Russell2019-18) It remains infective for up to two hours in that airspace or nearby surfaces. [[26]](#cite_note-Pink2016-26) [[50]](#cite_note-CDC2018Health-50) Measles is so contagious that if one person has it, 90% of non-immune people who have close contact with them (e.g., household members) will also become infected. [[26]](#cite_note-Pink2016-26) [[51]](#cite_note-pmid31480896-51) Humans are the only natural hosts of the virus, and no other animal [reservoirs](/wiki/Natural_reservoir) are known to exist, although mountain gorillas are believed to be susceptible to the disease. [[26]](#cite_note-Pink2016-26) [[52]](#cite_note-pmid24450064-52) Risk factors for measles virus infection include [immunodeficiency](/wiki/Immunodeficiency) caused by [HIV/AIDS](/wiki/HIV/AIDS), [[53]](#cite_note-53) [immunosuppression](/wiki/Immunosuppression) following receipt [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) travel to areas where measles commonly occurs or contact with travelers from such an area; [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) and the loss of passive, inherited antibodies before the age of routine immunization. [[55]](#cite_note-Leuridan2012-55) Pathophysiology Once the measles virus gets onto the [mucosa](/wiki/Mucous_membrane), [[56]](#cite_note-Lancet2012-56) [[57]](#cite_note-Text2009-57) Measles virus uses a protein on its surface called [hemagglutinin](/wiki/Hemagglutinin) (H protein), to bind to a target receptor on the host cell, which could be [CD46](/wiki/CD46), which is expressed on all nucleated human cells, [CD150](/wiki/CD150), aka signaling lymphocyte activation molecule or SLAM, which is found on immune cells like B or T cells, and antigen-presenting cells, or [nectin-4](/wiki/Nectin-4), a cellular adhesion molecule. [[56]](#cite_note-Lancet2012-56) [[58]](#cite_note-58) Once bound, the fusion, or F protein helps the virus fuse with the membrane and ultimately get inside the cell. [[56]](#cite_note-Lancet2012-56) As the virus is a [single-stranded negative-sense RNA virus](/wiki/Negative-sense_single-stranded_RNA_virus), it includes the enzyme [RNA-dependent RNA polymerase](/wiki/RNA-dependent_RNA_polymerase) (RdRp) which is used genome into a positive-sense mRNA strand. [[56]](#cite_note-Lancet2012-56) After entering a cell, it is ready to be translated into viral proteins, wrapped in the cell's lipid envelope, and sent out of the cell as a newly made virus. [[59]](#cite_note-59) Within days, the measles virus spreads through local tissue and is picked up by [dendritic cells](/wiki/Dendritic_cells) and [alveolar macrophages](/wiki/Alveolar_macrophages), and carried from that local tissue in the lungs to the local lymph nodes. [[56]](#cite_note-Lancet2012-56) [[57]](#cite_note-Text2009-57) From there it continues to spread, eventually getting into the blood and spreading to more lung tissue, as well as other organs like the intestines and the brain. [[26]](#cite_note-Pink2016-26) [[56]](#cite_note-Lancet2012-56) Functional impairment of the infected dendritic cells by the measles virus is thought to contribute to measles-induced immunosuppression. [[6]](#cite_note-Rot2016-6) Diagnosis Typically, clinical [diagnosis](/wiki/Diagnosis) begins with the onset of [fever](/wiki/Fever) and [malaise](/wiki/Malaise) about 10 days after exposure to the measles virus, followed by the emergence of [cough](/wiki/Cough), [coryza](/wiki/Rhinitis), and [conjunctivitis](/wiki/Conjunctivitis) that worsen in severity over 4 days of appearing. [[60]](#cite_note-60) Observation of Koplik's spots is also diagnostic. [[31]](#cite_note-baxby-31) Other possible condition that can result in these symptoms [parvovirus](/wiki/Parvovirus), [dengue fever](/wiki/Dengue_fever), [Kawasaki disease](/wiki/Kawasaki_disease), and is however strongly recommended. [[62]](#cite_note-62) Laboratory testing Laboratory diagnosis of measles can be done with confirmation of positive measles [IgM antibodies](/wiki/IgM_antibodies) or detection of measles virus RNA from throat, nasal or urine specimen by using the [reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction](/wiki/Reverse_transcription_polymerase_chain_reaction) assay. [[61]](#cite_note-:6-61) [[63]](#cite_note-:5-63) This method is particularly useful to confirm cases when the IgM antibodies results are inconclusive. [[61]](#cite_note-:6-61) For people unable to have their [blood drawn](/wiki/Phlebotomy), saliva can be collected for salivary measles-specific [IgA](/wiki/IgA) testing. [[63]](#cite_note-:5-63) Salivary tests used to diagnose measles involve collecting a saliva sample and testing for the presence of measles antibodies. [[64]](#cite_note-:3-64) [[65]](#cite_note-:4-65) This method is not ideal, as saliva contains many other fluids and proteins which may make it difficult to collect samples and detect measles antibodies. [[64]](#cite_note-:3-64) [[65]](#cite_note-:4-65) Saliva also contains 800 times fewer antibodies than blood samples do, which makes salivary testing additionally difficult. Positive contact with other people known to have measles adds evidence to the diagnosis. [[64]](#cite_note-:3-64) Prevention Mothers who are immune to measles pass antibodies to their children while they are still in the womb, especially if the mother acquired immunity through infection rather than vaccination. [[26]](#cite_note-Pink2016-26) [[55]](#cite_note-Leuridan2012-55) Such antibodies will usually give newborn infants some immunity against measles, but these antibodies are gradually lost over the course of the first nine months of life. [[27]](#cite_note-Merk2018Pro-27) [[55]](#cite_note-Leuridan2012-55) Infants under one year of age whose maternal anti-measles antibodies have disappeared become susceptible to infection with the measles virus. [[55]](#cite_note-Leuridan2012-55) In developed countries, it is recommended that children be immunized against measles at 12 months, generally as part of a three-part [MMR vaccine](/wiki/MMR_vaccine) (measles, [mumps](/wiki/Mumps), and [rubella](/wiki/Rubella)). The vaccine is generally not given before this age because such infants respond inadequately to the vaccine due to an immature immune system. [[55]](#cite_note-Leuridan2012-55) A second dose of the vaccine is usually given to children between the ages of four and five, to increase rates of immunity. Measles vaccines have been given to over a billion people. [[18]](#cite_note-Russell2019-18) Vaccination rates have been high enough to make measles relatively uncommon. Adverse reactions to vaccination are rare, with fever and pain at the injection site being the most common. Life-threatening adverse reactions occur in less than one per million vaccinations (<0.0001%). [[66]](#cite_note-cubavac-66) In developing countries where measles is [common](/wiki/Endemic_(epidemiology)), the [World Health Organization](/wiki/World_Health_Organization) (WHO) recommends two doses of [vaccine](/wiki/Vaccine) be given, at six and nine months of age. The vaccine should be given whether the child is HIV-infected or not. [[67]](#cite_note-67) The vaccine is less effective in HIV-infected infants than in the general population, but early treatment with antiretroviral drugs can increase its effectiveness. [[68]](#cite_note-68) Measles vaccination programs are often used to deliver other child health interventions as well, such as bed nets to protect against [malaria](/wiki/Malaria), antiparasite medicine and vitamin A supplements, and so contribute to the reduction of child deaths from other causes. [[69]](#cite_note-69) The [Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices](/wiki/Advisory_Committee_on_Immunization_Practices) (ACIP) recommends that all adult international travelers who do not have positive evidence of previous measles immunity receive two doses of MMR vaccine before traveling, although birth before 1957 is presumptive evidence of immunity. [[70]](#cite_note-ACIP2013-70) Those born in the United States before 1957 are likely to have been naturally infected with measles virus and generally need not be considered susceptible. [[71]](#cite_note-71) [[26]](#cite_note-Pink2016-26) There have been false claims of an association between the measles vaccine and [autism](/wiki/Autism); this incorrect concern has reduced the rate of vaccination and increased the number of cases of measles where immunization rates became too low to maintain [herd immunity](/wiki/Herd_immunity). [[17]](#cite_note-Medscape2018-17) Additionally, there have been false claims that measles infection protects against cancer. [[18]](#cite_note-Russell2019-18) Administration of the MMR vaccine may prevent measles after exposure to the virus (post-exposure prophylaxis). [[72]](#cite_note-:10-72) Post-exposure prophylaxis guidelines are [Passive immunization](/wiki/Immunization) against measles by an [intramuscular injection](/wiki/Intramuscular_injection) of antibodies could be effective up to the seventh day after exposure. [[73]](#cite_note-pmid24687262-73) Compared to no treatment, the risk of measles infection is reduced by 83%, and the risk of death by measles is reduced by 76%. [[73]](#cite_note-pmid24687262-73) However, the effectiveness of passive immunization in comparison to active measles vaccine is not clear. [[73]](#cite_note-pmid24687262-73) The MMR vaccine is 95% effective for preventing measles after one dose if the vaccine is given to a child who is 12 months or older; if a second dose of the MMR vaccine is given, it will provide immunity in 99% of children. [[74]](#cite_note-74) There is no evidence that the measles vaccine virus can be transmitted to other persons. [[75]](#cite_note-75) Treatment There is no specific [antiviral treatment](/wiki/Antiviral_treatment) if measles develops. [[50]](#cite_note-CDC2018Health-50) Instead the medications are generally aimed at treating superinfections, maintaining good hydration with adequate fluids, and pain relief. [[50]](#cite_note-CDC2018Health-50) Some groups, like young children and the severely malnourished, are also given [vitamin A](/wiki/Vitamin_A), which acts as an [immunomodulator](/wiki/Immunotherapy#Immunomodulators) that boosts the antibody responses to measles and decreases the risk of serious complications. [[50]](#cite_note-CDC2018Health-50) [[76]](#cite_note-:8-76) [[77]](#cite_note-Vac2017-77) Medications Treatment is [supportive](/wiki/Supportive_treatment), with [ibuprofen](/wiki/Ibuprofen) or [paracetamol (acetaminophen)](/wiki/Paracetamol) to reduce fever and pain and, if required, a fast-acting [medication to dilate the airways](/wiki/Bronchodilator) for cough. [[78]](#cite_note-78) As for [aspirin](/wiki/Aspirin), some research has suggested a correlation between children who take aspirin and the development of [Reye syndrome](/wiki/Reye_syndrome). [[79]](#cite_note-79) [[80]](#cite_note-80) The use of [vitamin A](/wiki/Vitamin_A) during treatment is recommended to decrease the risk of blindness; [[77]](#cite_note-Vac2017-77) however, it does not prevent or cure the disease. [[81]](#cite_note-81) A [systematic review](/wiki/Systematic_review) of trials into its use found no reduction in overall mortality, but two doses (200 000 [IU](/wiki/International_unit)) of [vitamin A](/wiki/Vitamin_A) was shown to reduce mortality for measles in children younger than two years of age. [[76]](#cite_note-:8-76) [[82]](#cite_note-pmid16235283-82) It is unclear if [zinc](/wiki/Zinc) supplementation in children with measles affects outcomes as it has not been sufficiently studied. [[83]](#cite_note-83) There are no adequate studies on whether Chinese medicinal herbs are effective. [[84]](#cite_note-84) Prognosis Most people survive measles, though in some cases, complications may occur. About 1 in 4 individuals will be hospitalized and 1-2 in 1000 will die. Complications are more likely in children under age 5 and adults over age 20. [[85]](#cite_note-85) [Pneumonia](/wiki/Pneumonia) is the most common fatal complication of measles infection and accounts for 56-86% of measles-related deaths. [[86]](#cite_note-86) Possible consequences of include [laryngotracheobronchitis](/wiki/Laryngotracheobronchitis), [sensorineural hearing loss](/wiki/Sensorineural_hearing_loss), [[49]](#cite_note-Cohen2014-49) and—in about 1 in 10,000 to 1 in 300,000 cases [[87]](#cite_note-Noyce2012-87)— [panencephalitis](/wiki/Subacute_sclerosing_panencephalitis), which is usually fatal. [[88]](#cite_note-ninds.nih.gov-88) Acute measles encephalitis is another serious risk of measles virus infection. It typically occurs two days to one week after the measles [rash](/wiki/Exanthem) breaks out and begins with very high fever, severe headache, [convulsions](/wiki/Convulsion) and altered mentation. A person with measles encephalitis may become [comatose](/wiki/Coma), and death or brain injury may occur. [[89]](#cite_note-89) For people having had measles, it is rare to ever have a symptomatic reinfection. [[90]](#cite_note-90) The measles virus can deplete previously acquired [immune memory](/wiki/Immunological_memory) by killing cells that make antibodies, and thus weakens the immune system, which can cause deaths from other diseases. [[40]](#cite_note-Amnesia-40) [[41]](#cite_note-Mina_2019-41) [[42]](#cite_note-Nature-42) Suppression of the immune system by measles lasts about two years and has been epidemiologically implicated in up to 90% of childhood deaths in [third world](/wiki/Third_World) countries, and historically may have caused rather more deaths in the United States, the UK and Denmark than were directly caused by measles. [[91]](#cite_note-pmid25954009-91) Although the measles vaccine contains an attenuated strain, it does not deplete immune memory. [[41]](#cite_note-Mina_2019-41) Epidemiology Measles is extremely infectious and its continued circulation in a community depends on the generation of susceptible hosts by birth of children. In communities that generate insufficient new hosts the disease will die out. This concept was first recognized in measles by Bartlett in 1957, who referred to the minimum number supporting measles as the [critical community size](/wiki/Critical_community_size) (CCS). [[92]](#cite_note-92) Analysis of outbreaks in island communities suggested that the CCS for measles is around 250,000. [[93]](#cite_note-Black1966-93) To achieve [herd immunity](/wiki/Herd_immunity), more than 95% of the community must be vaccinated due to the ease with which measles is transmitted from person to person. [[29]](#cite_note-Ludlow2015-29) In 2011, the WHO estimated that 158,000 deaths were caused by measles. This is down from 630,000 deaths in 1990. [[94]](#cite_note-Loz2012-94) As of 2018, measles remains a leading cause of vaccine-preventable deaths in the world. [[19]](#cite_note-Kabra2013-19) [[95]](#cite_note-95) In developed countries the mortality rate is lower, for example in England and Wales from 2007 to 2017 death occurred between two and three cases out of 10,000. [[96]](#cite_note-96) In children one to three cases out of every 1,000 die in the United States (0.1-0.2%). [[97]](#cite_note-97) In populations with high levels of malnutrition and a lack of adequate healthcare, mortality can be as high as 10%. [[7]](#cite_note-WHO2014-7) [[98]](#cite_note-98) In cases with complications, the rate may rise to 20-30%.[ [medical citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Identifying_reliable_sources_(medicine))] In 2012, the number of deaths due to measles was 78% lower than in 2000 due to increased rates of immunization among [UN member |Worldwide||4,211,431||1,374,083||836,338||580,287||462,186| Even in countries where vaccination has been introduced, rates may remain high. Measles is a leading cause of vaccine-preventable childhood mortality. Worldwide, the fatality rate has been significantly reduced by a vaccination campaign led by partners in the [Measles Initiative](/wiki/Measles_Initiative): the [American Red Cross](/wiki/American_Red_Cross), the United States [CDC](/wiki/Centers_for_Disease_Control_and_Prevention), [United Nations Foundation](/wiki/United_Nations_Foundation), [UNICEF](/wiki/UNICEF) and the WHO. Globally, measles fell 60% from an estimated 873,000 deaths in 1999 to 345,000 in 2005. [[106]](#cite_note-UNICEF-106) Estimates for 2008 indicate deaths fell further to 164,000 globally, with 77% of the remaining measles deaths in 2008 occurring within the Southeast Asian region. [[107]](#cite_note-107) There were 142,300 measles related deaths globally in 2018, of which most cases were reported from African and eastern Mediterranean regions. These estimates were slightly higher than that of 2017, when 124,000 deaths were reported due to measles infection globally. [[108]](#cite_note-:9-108) In 2000, the WHO established the Global Measles and Rubella Laboratory Network (GMRLN) to provide measles, [rubella](/wiki/Rubella), and [congenital rubella syndrome](/wiki/Congenital_rubella_syndrome). [[109]](#cite_note-:7-109) Data from 2016 to 2018 show that the most frequently detected measles virus [genotypes](/wiki/Genotype) are decreasing, suggesting that increasing global population immunity has decreased the number of chains of transmission. [[109]](#cite_note-:7-109) Cases reported in the first three months of 2019, were 300% higher than in the first three months of 2018, with outbreaks in every region of the world, even in countries with high overall vaccination coverage where it spread among clusters of unvaccinated people. [[110]](#cite_note-110) The numbers of reported cases as of mid-November is over 413,000 globally, with an additional 250,000 cases in DRC (as reported through their national system), similar to the increasing trends of infection reported in the earlier months of 2019, compared to 2018. [[108]](#cite_note-:9-108) In 2019, the total number of cases worldwide climbed to 869,770. The number of cases reported for 2020 is lower compare to 2019. [[111]](#cite_note-:12-111) According to the WHO, the [COVID-19 pandemic](/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic) hindered [vaccination campaigns](/wiki/Measles_vaccination) in at least 68 countries, including in countries that were experiencing outbreaks, which caused increased risk of additional cases. [[112]](#cite_note-112) [[111]](#cite_note-:12-111) Europe In England and Wales, though deaths from measles were uncommon, they averaged about 500 per year in the 1940s. Deaths diminished with the improvement of medical care in the 1950s but the incidence of the disease did not retreat until vaccination was introduced in the late 1960s. Wider coverage was achieved in the 1980s with the measles, [mumps](/wiki/Mumps) and [rubella](/wiki/Rubella), [MMR vaccine](/wiki/MMR_vaccine). [[113]](#cite_note-113) In 2013-14, there were almost 10,000 cases in 30 European countries. Most cases occurred in unvaccinated individuals and over 90% of cases occurred in Germany, Italy, Netherlands, Romania, and United Kingdom. [[29]](#cite_note-Ludlow2015-29) Between October 2014 and March 2015, a measles outbreak in the German capital of [Berlin](/wiki/Berlin) resulted in at least 782 cases. [[114]](#cite_note-Elizabeth_Whitman-114) In 2017, numbers continued to increase in Europe to 21,315 cases, with 35 deaths. [[160]](#cite_note-160) History Measles is of [zoonotic](/wiki/Zoonotic) origin, having evolved from [rinderpest](/wiki/Rinderpest), which infects cattle. [[161]](#cite_note-Furuse2010-161) A precursor of the measles began causing infections in humans as early as the 4th century BC [[162]](#cite_note-162) [[163]](#cite_note-163) or as late as after AD 500. [[161]](#cite_note-Furuse2010-161) The [Antonine Plague](/wiki/Antonine_Plague) of AD 165-180 has been speculated to have been measles, but the actual cause of this plague is unknown and smallpox is a more likely cause. [[164]](#cite_note-164) The first systematic description of measles, and its distinction from smallpox and [chickenpox](/wiki/Chickenpox), is credited to the [Persian](/wiki/Medicine_in_medieval_Islam) physician [Muhammad ibn Zakariya al-Razi](/wiki/Rhazes) (860-932), who published The Book of Smallpox and Measles. [[165]](#cite_note-165) At the time of Razi's book, it is believed that outbreaks were still limited and that the virus was not fully adapted to humans. Sometime between AD 1100 and 1200, the measles virus fully diverged from rinderpest, becoming a distinct virus that infects humans. [[161]](#cite_note-Furuse2010-161) This agrees with the observation that measles requires a susceptible population of >500,000 to sustain an epidemic, a situation that occurred in historic times following the growth of medieval European cities. [[93]](#cite_note-Black1966-93) Measles is an [endemic disease](/wiki/Endemic_disease), meaning it has been continually present in a community and many people develop resistance. In populations not exposed to measles, exposure to the new disease can be devastating. In 1529, a measles outbreak in [Cuba](/wiki/Cuba) killed two-thirds of those indigenous people who had previously survived smallpox. Two years later, measles was responsible for the deaths of half the population of [Honduras](/wiki/Honduras), and it has ravaged [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico), [Central America](/wiki/Central_America), and the [Inca](/wiki/Inca) civilization. [[167]](#cite_note-167) Between roughly 1855 and 2005, measles is estimated to have killed about 200 million people worldwide.
